metadata.title: Augmentative and Alternative Communication  Children with Intellectual DisabilityEvaluation and therapeutic services for augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) for children with intellectual disability (ID)

description: Augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) is a communication system that supplements or replaces verbal communication (speech) and includes four main components: symbols, aids, strategies, and techniques(1) –Symbols can include objects, drawings, photographs, or print (e.g., words, letters, sentences)(1) –Aids can be relatively simple or complex devices (e.g., communication boards, electronic devices) for transmitting or receiving messages(1) –Strategies refer to the methods by which symbols can be conveyed in the easiest and most efficient manner(1) –Techniques refer to the ways in which the messages are selected for transmission (e.g., direct selection, scanning)(1)

ID can be caused by injury, disease, or a brain abnormality –Prenatal causes of ID include:(4) -Genetic conditions (e.g., Down syndrome, fragile X syndrome)(4) -Inborn errors of metabolism (e.g., phenylketonuria [PKU] – can lead to ID if not treated)(4) -Brain malformations(4) -Maternal disease(4) -Environmental influences (e.g., alcohol, drugs, toxins, teratogens)(4) –Perinatal causes of ID include:(4) -Labor and delivery events that lead to neonatal encephalopathy(4) -Low birth weight(58) –Postnatal causes include:(4) -Hypoxic ischemic injury(4) -Traumatic brain injury (TBI)(4)  -Infections(4) -Demyelinating disorders(4) -Seizure disorders(4) -Poverty and cultural deprivation(4,58) -Toxic metabolic syndromes and intoxications (e.g., lead, mercury)(4) –Researchers in the United States studied prenatal and perinatal risk factors associated with ID in a large cohort of 8-year-old  children in Utah (N = 26,108) using information from birth records.(58) Risk factors that were identified were poly/oligohydramnios (too much or too little amniotic fluid), advanced paternal/maternal age, prematurity, fetal distress, premature rupture of membranes, primary/repeat cesarean sections, low birth weight, assisted ventilation greater than 20 minutes, small-for-gestational age, low Apgar scores, and congenital infections. Socioeconomic disadvantage maintained a prominent association with increased ID risk when underlying genetic disorders were excluded –In approximately half of patients with ID, the cause is unknown(2) –For detailed information on communication disorders in children with ID, see Clinical Review…Communication Disorders: School-Aged  Children with Intellectual Disability ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709139

The terms global developmental delay and developmental delay are often used instead of ID to describe children under the age of 5 years but have also been used to describe children over the age of 5 years(3) –Global developmental delay refers to a significant delay (two or more standard deviations) across at least two or more developmental domains(3)

For individuals who are school-aged  and older, the term intellectual disability is now preferred over the term mental retardation by the American Association on Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities (AAIDD). The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5 ) diagnostic criteria for ID are as follows: –Significantly below average intellectual functioning confirmed by clinical assessment and individualized, standardized intelligence testing(4) –Deficits or impairments in adaptive functioning. Adaptive deficits negatively affect functioning in one more ADLs (e.g., communication, social participation, independent living) across multiple environments(4) –Deficits in intellectual and adaptive functioning are evident during the “developmental period”(4)

The DSM-5  specifies degrees of severity of ID (mild, moderate, severe, profound) based on adaptive functioning, not based on IQ, because adaptive functioning determines how much support is needed.(4) According to the DSM-5 , adaptive functioning should be assessed with both clinical evaluation as well as individualized, culturally appropriate, psychometrically sound assessments(4)
The AAIDD also classifies severity in terms of support needed for adaptive skills areas (intermittent, limited, extensive, or pervasive support needed)(5)
Prevalence of ID in the United States is approximately 1%(5)

The symptoms of a communication disorder in children with ID vary considerably between children and are influenced by the child’s age, the severity of accompanying motor or cognitive impairments, the child’s medical status, the child’s home environment, and/or the presence or absence of hearing and/or vision loss.(6,54) Children with ID can exhibit problems in the areas of producing vocalizations and/or speech, receptive language, expressive language (including the use of gesture), and/or social language (pragmatics)(6)
For detailed information on assessment and treatment of communication disorders in children with developmental and intellectual disabilities, please see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
indications: The child has difficulty communicating using oral language because of an impairment of speech, receptive, and/or expressive language abilities –Authors of a study conducted in Ireland to identify the range of technology needs of children with complex needs included the families of 178 children with ID. Authors of the study found that 35% of parents reported using some type of AAC.(47) The AAC utilized voice-,  eye-,  or touch-activated  technology(47)

reimbursement: In the United States, applications for AAC devices can be submitted by a speech-language  pathologist (SLP) or a durable medical equipment provider to Medicare, Medicaid, V ocational Rehabilitation, and other insurers. See http://www.aacfundinghelp.com/  for information on AAC funding and a template for a funding report. In many European countries, SLPs are able to contact AAC device manufacturers directly to initiate the evaluation and funding procedures(41) Guidelines for use of AAC
contraindications precautions to test: Language deficits in children with ID are often influenced by difficulties and impairments in nonlinguistic domains such as social anxiety, hearing loss, vision loss, a compromised immune system, and motor difficulties. The SLP should take into account nonlinguistic domains when assessing the child and evaluating performance(10)

Parents/caregivers and school personnel should be involved in both assessment and treatment. They have a unique perspective and can provide information about the child that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures(11)

The SLP needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning and when developing treatment goals. Communication needs of the child should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting(11)

The evaluation should be performed in all the languages to which the child is exposed. For children with severe ID, assessment should focus on preverbal behaviors such as play, gesture, and other forms of nonverbal communication(9)

Standardized assessment measures should be used in conjunction with ecologically valid measures such as observation of the child in his or her natural environment during typical or daily activities (e.g., during play)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Does the child have a diagnosis? When was the diagnosis made and by whom?(3)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary with respect to the etiology of the ID and presenting symptoms. Does the child have a history of prolonged hospitalization? What kind of medical management has the child received, including surgeries and rehabilitation?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for AAC with children with ID are the following:
Formal and informal speech, language, and communication assessment (for further information, see Relevant tests and measures , below)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home strategies or alternative therapies and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech-language,  occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there times of day in which the child’s communication is better or worse? -Are there times or situations in which the child is anxious or frustrated, particularly when trying to communicate? -Does the child communicate more effectively with certain persons? -Are there certain situations in which the child is a more successful communicator?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: The symptoms of communication disorders in children with ID are highly variable and can be influenced by a child’s diagnosis, the child’s age, the severity of accompanying motor or cognitive impairments, the child’s medical status, and the child’s home and/or school environment. Children with ID sometimes have problems in the areas of producing vocalizations and/or speech, receptive language, expressive language (including the use of gesture), and/or social language (pragmatics)(6) -How does the child communicate; by gesture, words, or in other ways? -What words or gestures does the child use? What intentions does the child attempt to express? -Who understands the child's communication? -How well does the child understand various modes of communication?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document any sleep disturbances. Sleep disturbances are common in children with ID.(5,50) Factors that can contribute to sleep disturbances are obesity, enlarged tonsils, gastroesophageal reflux, and lack of sufficient exercise/activity(5)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Examples include hemianopia (partial blindness), depression, motor deficits, dysphagia, apraxia, dysarthria, poor overall health status, and seizures
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have respiratory difficulties? Does the patient have a tracheostomy?A family’s needs and priorities should be discussed during an assessment, either formally or informally. Problem behaviors are more common in children with ID than in typically developing children, with the highest levels found in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) or cerebral palsy(12)  -Parental stress has been found to be associated with syndrome-specific  behavioral patterns(12) -A parent’s stress level and psychosocial well-being can have a significant impact on the child’s quality of life. In a research study conducted in the Netherlands with 130 parents of children with ID, researchers found that the strongest predictors of the child’s quality of life were related to the parent’s social well-being.(42) When social activities for the parent were restricted due to caregiver duties for the child, both parental social well-being  and child quality of life suffered(42) -Children with identified or suspected developmental and/or intellectual disabilities are less likely to receive responsive parenting (in which parents are highly attuned to their child’s needs and parenting style constantly evolves as the child develops) than their typically developing peers; education and support for the parents of a child with ID are extremely important(13) -Patient and family quality of life should be considered throughout evaluation and treatment of a child with ID.(43,44,45,48) Results of studies conducted with Chinese, Belgian, Turkish, and Malaysian families and siblings of children with ID have indicated that having a family member with ID can significantly reduce quality of life, especially for the parent(s) of the child(43,44,45,48,59) -Refer to social services and/or psychiatric professional as appropriateHas the child’s hearing been screened? If hearing loss is suspected, refer to an audiologist for a full evaluation Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the child been seen by any other specialist for developmental delay in any area? Is there a family history of developmental disability or ID?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient’s family/caregivers about other problems, including behavior problems, motor difficulties, and selfinjurious  behavior. Children with developmental disabilities and ID are more likely to have Etiology-specific  coexisting conditions (e.g., children with Down syndrome are at risk for hearing impairment, vision difficulties, celiac disease, and hypothyroidism)(5)20% to 30% of children with ID also have a diagnosis of ASD(5)ADHD is present in 9% to 15% of children with ID(5)The prevalence of sensory impairments in children with mild ID is 2%; in children with severe ID, it is 11%(5)The prevalence of psychiatric and behavioral disturbances in children with ID is estimated to be as high as 80%(5)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient,family, and/or caregivers about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Things to consider include -Does the child currently receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, or clinic based? -If the child is school-aged,  what is the school placement? Classroom, small group, 1-on-1  aide? -In what kind of toys or activities is the child most interested? -How does the child communicate thoughts, wants, and needs in various settings and with various communication partners (e.g., gestures, eye gaze, vocalizations, words)?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: The absence of functional communication can significantly impact an individual’s ability to participate in ADLs. During an assessment, the SLP should consider ways to support a child’s participation in ADLs. This should be done in collaboration with the patient, family/caregiver, other medical personnel, and school/work staff(14) -What ADLs can the child perform? -At what age were developmental milestones reached?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, siblings). Identify if there are barriers to age-appropriate  independence in the home; any modifications necessary? What language does the patient speak at home, at school, and in the community? How familiar/comfortable is the family with technology?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Does the patient have any hemiparesis, paralysis, or other motor difficulties that may affect ability to use AAC? Refer to an OT or PT for an evaluation to determine the best way to access AAC as needed
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Review child’s medical records and document any sensory impairments, including hearing and vision loss. The decision about which types of AAC are appropriate for the child to use will be affected by the presence of any sensory impairments –In a study conducted in India with 241 children with ID (ages 6–16),  researchers found that 51.45% of them had problems related to the eyes, including refractive error (which causes reduced visual acuity), strabismus, and cataracts(49)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)If the child uses some speech for communication, use a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis to determine speech errors. A speech sound inventory can be completed for children who have severely limited speech. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be completedSchool-aged  children with severe to profound ID may be in the early developmental stages of communication. The impact of any motor difficulties should be considered when evaluating the child’s ability to respond to and initiate communication. Early communication can be assessed informally by means of a language sample and observation that document forms (e.g., gesture, vocalizations) and functions of communication (e.g., requests,(19) The CSBS assesses expressive language, social communication, and symbolic abilities by means of a parent report and direct interactions with a child.an infant-toddler  checklist, a caregiver questionnaire, and a 30-minute  behavior sample of the child. It can be used with children aged 6 to 24 months and with children up to age 6 years who have a developmental level below 24 months(20) Used to assess prelinguistic communication behaviors in individuals with severe developmental and/or physical disabilities. Administered as a questionnaire to be completed by parents, teachers, and therapists. Pragmatic functions that are assessed include social convention, attention to self, rejection/ protestation, request for an object, request for action, request for information, comment, choice making, answer, and imitation(21) Designed to identify how the child currently communicates and assist the assessment team in selecting appropriate communication goals. The assessment covers communication skills that would typically occur from birth to 24 months of age. It can be used for individuals of all ages who are at the earliest stages of communication –Parent-child  interactions(35,55) An instrument to assess the communicative style of parents as they interact with their children using AAC. A copy of the scale and instructions can be retrieved at dart-gbg.org/public/anpassningar/RAACS%20Version%203_130108.doc -Researchers in Sweden developed the RAACS scale to assess the communicative style of parents as they engaged in play interactions (videotaped) with their children using AAC. The researchers found that the scale showed acceptable inter-  and intra-coder  reliability and excellent internal consistency. Used pre- and postintervention, the measure  indicated changes in the communication behavior of a treatment group but not in the control group. Treatment focused on improving the responsiveness of parent communication and the modeling of AAC use by parentsMany standardized language tests include separate standardized scores for children with mild ID. However, a review of standardized tests found that many do not include a large normative sample and that most do not measure a student’s pragmatic communication.(22) No tests included students with more severe ID in the normative sample.(22) Children with ID often have impairment of receptive and expressive language skills; for some children, receptive language skills will be more impaired than expressive language skills, whereas in others expressive is more impaired relative to receptive.(46) SLPs should always supplement standardized tests with informal language assessment procedures to assess students’ pragmatic, social, and functional communication abilities. Standardized tests may have to be adapted so that the child can respond and answer in alternative ways. Some standardized tests that provide standardized scores for -Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals, 5thedition (CELF-5)(23) -Comprehensive Assessment of Spoken Language, 2nd edition (CASL-2)(24) -Expressive One-Word  Picture V ocabulary Test, 4th edition (EOWPVT-4) -Oral and Written Language Scales, 2ndedition (OWLS - II)(25) -Test of Early Language Development, 4thedition (TELD-4)(26)5)(27)Briefly assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance; if there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document information about cognitive abilities, if known. The SLP can administer language-related  problem-solving tests, but other cognitive tests will most likely be administered by a school psychologist or special education teacher (e.g., the School Inventory of Problem-Solving  Skills [SIPSS])(15)
relevant tests and measures.aac assessment: The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) recommends that AAC assessment adhere to the participation model, which is based on the fact that all persons with disabilities can enhance communication ability.(1,16) The goal of an AAC assessment within the participation model is to match the child with optimal communication strategies and systems so that he or she can participate in meaningful events in daily life.(1) Assessment must consider the skills of the child as well as the setting and prospective conversational partners. A team approach is recommended in the implementation of AAC; team members typically include SLPs, teachers, the AAC user, and parents/ caregivers. To the greatest extent possible, assessment procedures should be applicable to everyday life(1,7)The purpose of an environmental assessment is to determine the extent of the child’s communication repertoire and social functions with respect to the child’s peers.(16) The following -A peer can be observed in a particular setting (e.g., classroom)(16) -The communication abilities of the child being considered for AAC are compared to those of his or her peers (e.g., asking questions, answering yes/no questions, greeting others, requesting objects or activities)(16) -The child is then provided the AAC support and taught the skills necessary to participate in the activity(16) -Positioning and location for each activity should be considered when selecting an AAC system(18) -Communication functions and specific messages (e.g., sharing information with classmates, asking for assistance) should be considered when selecting and programming an AAC device(18)A child’s knowledge of symbols is typically assessed through dynamic assessment, in which the symbols are taught to the child and then assessed. Symbols include gestures, line drawings, photographs, pictures, traditional orthography, and manual signs. Before assessment, a range of concepts that are functional and meaningful for the child are selected to be tested. Language tasks that can be used to test symbol(16,18)The evaluator says, “Show me…” while presenting multiple symbols in front of the childThe evaluator asks, “Is this a…?” while presenting a symbolThe child is asked to match a symbol to its referent The child is asked to answer questions using symbols that are availableThe child is given an opportunity to request an item by using a symbolThe organization of symbols in an aided system should reflect how the child organizes the symbols rather than how the SLP may organize them. Symbols can be arranged taxonomically, alphabetically, schematically, or idiosyncratically (e.g., the child puts “baseball” with “dad” because he plays baseball(18)The child groups individual vocabulary on different pages or in different boxesThe child is required to match words togetherThe child may trial one organizational system and changes may be made based on the child’s speed, accuracy, and preference in selecting itemsInterviews with the child’s caregivers, teachers, and other communicative partners might identify possible communication barriers that can be resolved. In addition, systematic observation of the child’s interactions, with focus on the communicative partners, can yield information on barriers that may limit the child’s opportunity to communicate. Sample barriers include lack of sufficient response time allowed for child, lack of child attention during communicative interactions, and environmental barriers such as presence of loud noises in the classroom(16,18)Note any difficulties the child has with motor control that interfere with social interaction and communication. Refer to physical therapist (PT) or occupational therapist (OT) as necessary

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Children with ID might be at risk for feeding and swallowing disorders; perform a feeding/swallowing evaluation if feeding/swallowing disorders are suspected or if the child exhibits signs of malnourishment

Children with ID might be at increased risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. If appropriate, ensure that patient, parents, and caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. If inpatient, hospital discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for procedure The need for AAC is determined through a comprehensive AAC assessment that examines the child’s present communicative skills, communicative needs, and future communicative goals AAC intervention should be a multidisciplinary and ongoing procedure that may require multiple systems over many years to accommodate changing cognitive, linguistic, and physical abilities Goals should be formulated by an AAC team that includes, at minimum, the SLP, the family, the teacher, and the AAC user(29) AAC use and implementation will vary considerably among persons with ID and depend on the specific disability. Many individuals with ID have multiple disabilities(54) –The child has socially unacceptable or harmful ways of communicating (e.g., hitting)(1) –Existing methods of communication are tiring or inefficient for the child(1) –Existing methods of communication are understood only by a limited number of familiar conversational partners(1)
prognosis: The overall prognosis for successful use of AAC for a child with ID depends on numerous variables, including the severity of motor disability, cognitive disability, psychosocial characteristics, presence of coexisting conditions, and community/ family support. Adaptive skill development can have a significant impact on the child’s future level of independence(5)

The presence of some degree of receptive language ability as well as comprehension of distal gestures indicate a good prognosis for a child’s ability to communicate symbolically using an AAC system(1)

Prognosis for AAC use depends on the above intrinsic factors as well as external factors that might be barriers to or facilitators of AAC use. Barriers that have been identified include time constraints, specific device problems, and lack of support from parents/caregivers(7)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Several professionals will likely be involved in the school assessment team and the treatment team for a child with ID(5)An OT may assist with fine motor and adaptive skills. Collaborate with the OT on AAC support as necessary (e.g., optimal way to access the device)Refer to a PT if the child has significant motor deficits and/or poor/weak posture that negatively affects speech production or manipulation of/ability to access an AAC deviceA recreational therapist may be involved to assist the child in developing recreational skillsSocial services can assist the family in negotiating assistance systems (e.g., medical services, daycare)Refer to a behavioral psychologist if the child exhibits any challenging behaviors, including self-injurious behaviors
treatment summary: Effective and efficient use of AAC occurs with a coordinated effort on the part of teachers, the SLP, the family, and the AAC user(7,29)
When implementing intervention, the SLP/teacher should consider the child’s preferences and functional motivations(30)

Rather than a single system of communication, the assessment team should identify multiple methods of communication that the child can use in different situations.(29) Some forms of AAC (e.g., manual signs) are more easily accessed but understood by only some communication partners; voice output communication aids (VOCAs) are more widely understood but may not be available at the moment that the child wants to communicate
Monitoring of the device or system should be ongoing due to the changing needs of the child and the level of required external support(7,29)

Treatment should be functional and family-centered  and/or school-centered  when possible. The child should be taught to use the AAC system functionally in diverse settings with different partners.(1) The SLP might be involved in providing direct coaching to parents and siblings regarding the use of the AAC device. Families should always have the opportunity to provide information on the children’s greatest communication needs(29)

The SLP will typically be involved in instructing teachers, paraeducators, and parents on how to use the AAC system with the child. Instruction will vary with the individual’s knowledge but might include providing information on the importance of communication, the relationship between behavior and communication, prompting students to use AAC, and how to respond to the student’s communicative attempts(31)

Modeling of the use of the device/system is an essential part of the instructional process. The teacher/SLP/caregiver models using the AAC system and integrates the system into his or her own communication during naturalistic and motivating situations. Modeling allows input experience for the child(32) –Enhanced milieu teaching (EMT): Features of EMT include: a) following the child’s attentional lead and establishing joint attention; b) using teaching episodes that are brief, positive, rewarding, and embedded within natural activities that occur throughout the child’s day; c) simultaneous teaching of form (syntax), content (vocabulary), and function (pragmatics); d) targeting general communication forms and functions that are on the boundary of the child’s productive communicative competence; and e) using mands (adult questions, commands, or directives)and models to elicit production of targets that are related to the child’s focus of attention.(51) The principles of EMT can be used as a means of modeling AAC

V ocabulary/symbol considerations –Target vocabulary used with the AAC system should be salient to the child and modeled in naturalistic, routine, and motivating situations(32) –It is important to include symbols to allow the child to communicate basic needs (e.g., food, drink, pain, toilet) but not to limit communication to basic needs and to also include symbols that assist the child in fostering social relationships(32) –When introducing new symbols, routine situations should be used so that the child’s attention can be focused on learning the new word rather than understanding a novel situation(32) –When choosing vocabulary to use with AAC, it is important to include people’s names to encourage social closeness(32) –Emotion labels are important for the child to talk about school and other past events. They also allow the child to communicate when he or she is frustrated(32) –Inclusion of action words will help foster more complex syntactic development or symbol combinations(31)

Access considerations –There are two ways of indicating symbols with aided AAC systems, direct selection and scanning. Direct selection involves the child directly selecting the symbol (e.g., using a finger, using eye gaze). For those who have difficulty with motor control, scanning may be used(32) –There are two kinds of scanning: electronic and partner-assisted: -In electronic scanning, the AAC device presents the choices electronically. For example, a light may go on next to each symbol one-by-one.  When a light indicates the desired symbol, the child selects it by hitting a switch.(32) Some devices allow for either direct selection or scanning -In partner-assisted  scanning, the communication partner scans through symbols one-by-one  (i.e., by pointing). When the partner arrives at the desired choice, the child indicates by vocalizing, moving an arm, or eye-blink(32)

Display presentation considerations: Presentation refers to the organization and layout of the concepts within a display. Variables in presentation include the permanence of the display (i.e., static vs. dynamic display), layout of the display (i.e., grid or visual scene displays), number of representations on the display, size of the symbols, and color organization(33) –In a static display, all symbols can be viewed simultaneously but are limited in number. In a dynamic display, the person can navigate different electronic or nonelectronic pages to find other symbols(33) –Symbols can be displayed on a grid (rows and columns of pictures) or as a visual scene display. A visual scene display contains a drawing or photograph with hot spots that allow the user to select items within the scene. For example, a scene may be a kitchen and the user can select an item of food. It is theorized that visual scene displays might reduce cognitive demands in finding and using correct symbols because the symbols are displayed in a contextually meaningful context(33) –Recent AAC applications developed for use on mainstream devices (mobile phones with texting, iPads, iPod Touch) have made AAC more affordable and more available, and have also given the users an opportunity to “blend in.”(52,53) There is some evidence that AAC users have a preference for an iPad-based  speech-generating  device over the traditional Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS).(17) For example, in a study in Sweden, researchers found that texting with picture symbols and speech increased independence and participation in communication exchanges in adults with complex communication needs and ID.(53) However, researchers caution that only minimal research has focused on improving the design and display of AAC technologies to maximize outcomes for children. Most of the available mobile technology apps have replicated traditional AAC interfaces that were developed in the early years of AAC and most are not based on research evidence. There is a need to develop new generation AAC systems that are responsive to the needs of children who use them(52)

AAC should be used with evidence-based  instructional procedures such as naturalistic teaching strategies.(32) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of communication disorders associated with developmental and intellectual disabilities, please see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

Types of AAC:  AAC is typically categorized into unaided systems of communication and aided systems of communication –Unaided communication:  Unaided approaches to AAC involve using the child’s body to communicate by means of manual signs, gestures, vocalizations, facial expressions, or body movements(34) -Sign language/manual signs: Manual signs may be a primary method of communication or part of a multimodal method of communicating. Even children who may usually use an aided method of communicating may need other methods, such as manual signs, when their electronic or nonelectronic aid is absent or malfunctions(36) -Advantages of sign language/gestures include portability, speed of message preparation, and access to an unlimited number of potential messages. Limitations include the requirement of sufficient fine motor skills to produce the signs; in addition, the signs/gestures need to be recognizable to the communication partner(37) -Use of manual signs is more effective when staff (e.g., teachers, aides, therapists) utilize the signs throughout the day across a variety of activities.(62) Simultaneous use of speech and signs has been shown to increase mean length of utterance in children with ID(63) –Aided communication: Aided communication approaches include light-technology  devices and high-tech devices -Light-technology  (low-tech)  systems:Light-technology AAC refers to nonelectronic external systems such as alphabet boards, symbol-based  topic boards, dry-erase  boards, and programs such as the PECS (see below for description)(37) -In all cases, patients who use AAC for communication should have a light-tech  component to their AAC system.(60) Because batteries and computers fail, no patient should only be trained in the use of an electronic device to communicate.(60) In addition to technology failures, the clinician must consider that one AAC device or method cannot meet all of a patient’s communication needs for all possible situations and speakers; hence, a low-tech  option (or multiple low-tech  options) should always be provided.(60) There is no one low-tech  option that works best for all patients; it is important to trial several different speech supplementation methods to determine which type increases functional communication the most(61) -Advantages of methods such as drawing and a dry-erase board over fixed communication systems such as a communication board are that they can be used in dynamic situations, allowing for expansion and modification of messages(37) -Because light-technology  systems do not have speech output, they require the active participation of the communication partner in interpreting and speaking the words that the child selects; thus, conversations can be highly interactive(37) -Light-technology  systems also allow frequent opportunities for the communication partner to model when he or she supplements spoken output by pointing to the corresponding symbol(37) -The success of the interaction depends on the communication partner’s knowledge of the topic, knowledge of the AAC system, and comfort in interacting with the system; thus, it is crucial that communication partners are trained in the use of the particular system with the child(37) -The most intervention research on light-technology systems for children with ID has been with PECS -PECS is a program that teaches the child to request and comment by giving picture cards to a communication partner.(38) The communication partner responds by modeling the verbal request and providing the requested item. The child is taught to use PECS by a series of shaping and prompting procedures. Single cards can be used, or cards can be combined into a sequence on a sentence strip and exchanged with the communication partner.(38) For detailed information on the strategies and the sequence of instructional steps for PECS, see Frost & Bondy, 1996(39) -In a multiple baseline study conducted in the United States across behaviors, PECS with peers was used to increase social interactions (greetings, requests, and responses) for two children (ages 6 years and 14 years) with severe developmental disabilities.(40) The peers were trained in how to respond to the child by taking the PECS icon and giving the requested item. Social interactions took place during group activities such as coloring, puzzles, and art projects. Results indicated that the two children both demonstrated a modest increase in social behaviors by using PECS as well as other forms of communication, such as spoken language and American Sign Language. The authors noted that the participants preferred the use of other forms of communication in combination with or as an alternative to PECS but that PECS provided a place to start when interacting with peers(40)  -In a multiple baseline study conducted in the United States, researchers provided preliminary evidence that a 9-year-old  boy with multiple disabilities, including severe ID and deaf-blindness,  could learn to use contextually referenced words (more, new, done) in a modified PECS procedure with tactile symbols.(57) The subject in this study was able to use conceptually referenced symbols to communicate about 12 different stimuli –High-technology  systems: High-technology  systems are electronic devices such as speech-generating  devices. Speech-generating  devices have been classified into two main types: devices that allow for formation of new messages and devices that use word or whole-phrase  retrieval of prerecorded messages. Caregivers and patients should be involved in selecting the device. Factors to consider when selecting a device include: -Appearance: The assessment team and patient should consider the size, type of pictures (symbolic, photographs), and hardware required. For example, a person who is mobile might want a smaller device for portability, whereas a person who is in a wheelchair may want a larger display for ease of use -Symbols should be culturally and individually relevant (e.g., if the patient participates in religious activities, options to allow for communication in these situations should be included) -Accessibility and ease of use: Many patients have paralysis or hemiparesis and portability should be considered. Can the patient use the device while holding it at the same time? Can the patient carry the device? -V oice quality: Is the voice quality clear? Does the patient have any difficulty perceiving the voice? -Effectiveness: Does the device meet the person’s communication needs? -Dynamic screen technology or static display? -Language demands: How are messages composed? Letters, single words, text plus symbols, phrases, sentences, visual scenes . maintenance or prevention: Authors of a qualitative study conducted in the United States of interviews with six special education teachers and one speech therapist who worked together on a school AAC team identified three factors that facilitated AAC use: Parent participation in the team process: AAC use was considered more successful when there was consistent communication between parents and school, when parents used the device with the child at home, and when parents participated in team decision-making(7) Effective team collaboration: Respondents reported that effective teaming required time, frequent communication, shared goals of building communication skills of students, administrative support for meetings and equipment needs, and support from all staff who were working with the students using AAC(7) Ease of use of device: Ease of use refers not only to ease of student use (e.g., portability, durability), but also ease of programming and maintenance(7)

Factors related to abandonment of AAC system include poor performance with the device, lack of significant improvement in communication with the device, high costs associated with the device (service, repair, maintenance), and limited availability of service and repair(1) Patient/Caregiver Education

Parents/caregivers and conversation partners should be instructed on how to provide the child with opportunities to communicate. The SLP might also educate caregivers/teachers on how to modify discourse to support the child(1)
The family and school professionals must be trained on how to use and program an electronic device(1)
